We ate here last night. Turns out we are staying in the hotel and were to tired to go back out.  While I agree with the other reviewers that it is pricey, it is the Mag Mile! The service was fantastic. We went late (after 9) and the bar was hopping. Rain had driven everyone inside from the patio. Dining room was a little slower, but that worked to our advantage. We had the Summer Menu Choice of lobster bisque, crab cake or salad. I had crab cake and my wife had the bisque. We both liked what we had very much. We both had the Fillet Mignon. It was to die for. Not sure why they give you, the steak knife. I could have cut it with a spoon!  Came with mashed potatoes and spinach. They mixed it together which was interesting. I liked it, but may not be for everyone. I had to pass on dessert but it looked great! All in all, I would go back.

A couple of years ago this place was a pricey, but not offensively expensive place to get a burger or sammich.  Last week I stopped in and the cheeseburger cost me SIXTEEN DOLLARS.  To make it worse it was kind of dry and tasteless.  Plus the bun had stale spots.  Service wasnt great either...started out good but then he vanished.  I guess they can get away with this since they have a steady stream of tourists.  If you want a much much better burger go down the block to Rosebud steakhouse on walton.

The Grill is a steakhouse hiding out in the Westin hotel.  They've been there for about a decade and I never noticed it, so they could use some PR, but the food is phenomenal! I went and started with the seared ahi tuna sashimi and it was better than many of the sushi houses I've had it it! It's worth going there just for that! For dinner, I had the bone in ribeye. Easily one of the best cuts of steak I've ever had. I mean, you can't go wrong with a 24 oz steak, but this one was exceptional! And they've got this mojito with muddled berries in it that's to die for! too bad it's always gone by the time I take a second look at my glass. They've got great burgers too, the kind you've got to unhinge your jaw just a little bit to bite into. Those are great too. and OMG strawberry shortcake that's out of this world! This place is fresh, well executed, and the staff is extremely friendly and knowledgeable.  It's a little pricey, but you definitely get what you pay for.

'Spensive little joint, but it's dang good. I didn't eat all day, so I got their cheapest steak, a side salad and some spinach and & artichoke dip. Everything was awesome, and the portions were huge. The spinach and artichoke dip was especially good... loved the little bread pieces that came with it. This place is right downstairs from the Westin (which is why I went) and if you think you're saving yourself on room service, it's probably not the case, but the food is awesome, nonetheless.

I was staying at the Westin, and due to a tight conference schedule, ended up eating her frequently for breakfast and some lunches.  Overall, the food is fine, nothing spectacular and no huge disappointments.  It's a little overpriced for what your really get, but that's what happens in hotel restaurants.  I still want to apologize to our server for the rude treatment he endured at the hands of a colleague--I'm sorry breakfast waiter guy!

Many of our friends were staying at the Westin when they came to town for our wedding last weekend, so we thought The Grill would be a good place to meet up.  At 9 pm on Saturday night about 20 people showed up to the bar all at once.  We got terrific service and I really, really enjoyed the ruby red grapefruit-lemon drop martini.  Yes, it was a $12 martini, but that is a hard thing to complain about in downtown Chicago.  Yum!

Spent a lot of time here when I was dating someone that lived in the Hancock.  He probably has his own barstool placard by now so I always received outstanding service. Food is a little pricey but I imagine its relative to the rents on Michigan Avenue.  Overpriced imo but I never had to pay.  Excellent steaks  that are tender and juicy.  Gigantic salads are decent as well.  I've probably had most things on the menu and the filet is really their stand out.  But its not Gibsons.

I came here for a last meal with my mom and her friend when they came to visit from ATL. Since they were charging $18 for a grilled chicken salad, I assumed the food would be good, and I expected fine dining service. The chicken salad my mom ordered had about 2 cubic inches of total chicken in it, and was disappointing all around. I had the lobster bisque, which was lukewarm and mediocre at best. I kept thinking how only a few blocks away, SoupBox would have served me far superior bisque for a few bucks less. The service was rushed and impersonal. Our bread (which I had to ask for) was cold, and the butter (which came with a very unappetizing piece of lettuce carelessly strewn on top) was nearly frozen. This place overcharges and underdelivers. Head over to SoupBox and you'll thank me later.

Great, vast menu, and I don't eat beef!!! Had some super yummy chicken. If I could remember our waiter's name, I'd give him a yelp, but he made some good non-beef recommendations! It is cool for the older crowd, like a dinner with mom&dad, which is who i diner with. Everyone went home happy and full!!! Boys, or single gals, hit the bar for some celeb-spotting if you're into baseball players, most teams stay there when they're in town!

So my coworker and i were only supposed to stop off in Chicago to board a connecting flight to Boston.  Today this is not what was in store for us.  After accepting the fact that we were staying an evening in Chicago, we had dinner at The Grill.  The ambiance is fairly nice.  It had a "frank sinatra" atmosphere and I can see that it would be the type of restaurant that should have a grand piano playing in the corner with a crooner singing.   We had a bottle of Savignon Blanc which was nice.  I am more of a red wine drinker, plus the fact that i have been drinking 8 days straight, i didn't consume too much.   Starters:  I had the lobster bisque soup.  It was good.  I inhaled it and the warm soup felt great in my belly.  Our server described it as "velvety", and yes it was velvety.   Side:  We also ordered the creamed spinach and the macaroni and cheese.  Honestly, i had better.  The spinach lacked an "ummph" that i was looking for, and the mac and cheese was good, but it wasn't creamy.  Yes, i like creamy mac and cheese.  Entree:  I ordered the only vegetarian dish.  Grilled vegetable with risotto.  Okay, the risotto was less to be desired and the vegetables so MUCH.  Like there had to have been a whole head of brocolli, bunch of onions, peppers, mushrooms, zuchinni.  It was just okay.  It had a funny sauce which i wasn't too fond of.   It was nice, and i'm glad i went.  But i didn't really make a dent in my food and i didn't want to take anything home to go.  So that must say something.

Perfectly adequate white napkin experience with no real risks or gaffes, either. The menu is vast and laden with tons of steaks, a slew of seafood, and decadent sides.  (Note to vegetarians: the hummus is quite edible and the pasta dish can be made as a primavera.)   Entrees, while enourmous in portion, are a flawless average. Dessets are surprisingly good - -the carrot cake is out of this world and the daily sorbet is a delighful surprise. Service is attentive and deliberate. A good resource for a decent North Michigan Ave meal.

A decent bar area for a small pre-show meal before Lookingglass. My friend and I were both disappointed in the Manhattan clam chowder. It tasted more like minestrone to us and seemed to be missing the clam all together. We split the spinach dip - that was much more tasty. Atmosphere was warm and cozy, and the patrons seemed to be your typical after-work crowd. Service was average. A little on the pricey side -  $50 for appetizers for two people (with only one alcoholic, and one non-alcoholic beverage).

I've had a relationship with this bar forever...And please note I am reviewing the BAR only and not the restaurant. Many moons ago--before Michigan Ave. morphed into the Midwest's Rodeo Drive--the bar portion of the Westin Hotel actually stretched onto the street. There was a jukebox and a pool table and the place could probably accomodate 200 people comfortably. The Westin people then sold part of the property to accomodate shops and the restaurant/bar became The Chelsea. I was in grad school then and knew someone who bartended there and we hung out there all the time. We'd play pool and drink $4.50 Miller Lites (in 1998 they were $4.50-yo!) and people-watch. During this stage of the bar I enjoyed many celebrity sitings: Slash from GnR, James Carville and Mary Matlin, Barry Bonds...Also: lots of scary rich older married dudes bought me drinks. Which was cool then because I was very poor. (well, still am, but also desperate back then.) Around 1999 it became The Grill on the Alley. I moved away though it wasn't until 2004 that I started frequenting the spot again.  The food is pretty good. Last night I enjoyed appetizer scallops ($13) that came in a yummy orange sauce and enabled me to hold my two whisky drinks. I've also had most of the salads ($11-15), but never any of the steaks. They have a hummus trio plate that is also quite good. No nuts though, which was a staple in the old days... The bar, though still sizable, is usually packed these days and that annoys me. Why can't the tourists leave their hotels and discover our wonderful city? I work nearby and would like to read my magazine in peace! (As in: no one using the tired "where are you from?" line.) But whatever. It remains one of my safety places.

Of course this place is good, it's in prime tourist area, over-priced and in a hotel; it should be at least decent even if lacking character.  We were dragged here with the promise of free dinner and drinks by my fiance's co-workers, and we were not disappointed.  We did go in with low expectations, only because this isn't really our "type" of place.  All in all though, we were pleasantly surprised and completely enjoyed ourselves!  (How could you not with a free meal? :o) )  Any way, I had a fabulous chopped Cobb salad with an outstanding glass of white, and the fiancee had a tasty prime-rib sandwich also paired with a great glass!  At any rate, if you don't mind the prices and you're in the area, check this place out!

The food here is great and the portions are huge. I had the chicken pot pie which was very creamy with the perfect flaky crust. It was easily big enough for two people to share, and you should, because even better than the main courses are their desserts. My table had the key lime pie and the strawberry shortcake, and every last bit was gone by the time we were finished. The service was attentive and friendly(although we were there for an early dinner on a Friday night  so it wasn't too busy) and the prices are exactly what you would expect from a restaurant in the Westin on Michigan Avenue.
Very delicious Easter Brunch with a large selection at a decent price!
Unreal beef.  Eat in the bar area for quick access to alcohol and less stuffiness.  Prices are what you'd expect for a place in the Westin.  It's worth it, though.

The Grill was great.  Inside the Westin Hotel, this classy place was nice from the opening cocktail to the end of dessert.  We even walked around to the bar area after the meal and had another drink or two before leaving.   I expected a place like this to be extremely pricey and full of pretension.... We were happy to find that neither could be said about the Grill.   We really enjoyed the wine selection.  The kitchen knows how to temp a steak, which is always a plus.  My GF had a the peppercorn filet medallions - it was much too peppery for me, but she enjoyed it.  We had a party of four, one person in our party was a vegetarian, and all were pleasantly surprised with how satisfied we were.   Eveyone's needs were met and all enjoyed the meal.This was a complete dining experience.

If you wonder where powerful business men would talk about making million dollar deals would go for dinner?  This is it. Leather booths, dim lights, walls layered with drawings. The wife and I split the crab cocktail - which was out of this world, especially the cocktail sauce.  I had the Prime Rib - which just melted in my mouth.  I'll admit for only $30 - it's the best prime rib I've ever had.  It comes with baked potato, and creamed spinach.  The wife had the tuna which was done to perfection.  Their wine selection was quite extensive and we were VERY happy with our $40 bottle. For dessert - I highly suggest the brownie pie and ice cream.  It was basically a fudge brownie with ice cream, then caramel, fudge, and topped off with candied pecans.

This is a restaurant inside of the Westin Hotel. The ambience and the atmosphere are great. Dim lights and the leather booths make a very romantic, yet comfortable setting. I have been here for dinner several times. The menu is pretty extensive and there's lots of different options, including steak and seafood. But what I enjoy even more than the food here is the dessert. The cheesecake here is absolutely delicious. So save room for dessert, because its something you won't want to miss!
